hypotheses: Lower caste households in villages dominated by low castes (Backward Agricultural Castes) have higher agricultural incomes than those in villages dominated by upper castes.
Caste dominance affects access to resources like irrigation, impacting economic outcomes for lower caste households.
claim.hypotheses_location: The hypotheses related to agricultural incomes and resource access due to caste dominance are discussed throughout the sections on methodologies and results (e.g., in sections on comparative analysis and empirical models).
claim.statement: The impact of caste dynamics on access to resources like irrigation significantly influences economic outcomes for lower caste households in rural India.
claim.statement_location: The main claim is encapsulated in the introduction and results sections, which discuss the effects of caste on economic transactions and outcomes.

data.source: UP-Bihar Living Standards Measurement Survey (LSMS) conducted by the World Bank
data.wave_or_subset: Data was collected from 120 rural villages, specifically focusing on village and household characteristics.
data.notes: Data collection includes village-level questionnaires and household surveys focusing on literacy, income, crop yields, and irrigation access.

method.description: The study uses empirical data analysis to examine economic outcomes related to caste dominance and resource access, employing OLS and IV estimation models to analyze the impact of caste on agricultural incomes and irrigation usage.
steps: Classify villages by caste dominance (upper castes vs. Backward Agricultural Castes).
Collect and analyze data from 120 villages (63 in Uttar Pradesh, 57 in Bihar), using household surveys.
Apply Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) and Instrumental Variables (IV) estimations to assess the economic outcomes.
Examine private groundwater markets and irrigation access as key factors.
Compare socioeconomic metrics such as literacy, crop yields, and income across village types.
method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) and Instrumental Variables (IV) estimation
method.independent_variables: Village caste composition, irrigation access, educational attainment, land ownership
method.control_variables: Geographic variables, hydrogeological factors, tenancy, and credit relations

results.summary: Lower caste households benefit from higher agricultural incomes in low-caste dominated villages due to improved access to irrigation resources, which highlights the significant role of caste in influencing economic outcomes.

metadata.original_paper_title: Caste Dynamics and Agrarian Incomes in Rural India
